examples.sentence: Learn group classification - identify verbs correctly
Master masu form first - safe, polite default
Practice common verbs - the 25 above cover daily needs
Learn te-form - unlocks many grammar patterns
Add plain forms gradually - for casual speech
No person or number (same form for I/you/he/they)
Only two tenses: past and non-past
Always come at the end of sentences

sections.heading: What Makes Japanese Verbs Unique
sections.content:
Japanese verbs are simpler than you think:

No person or number (same form for I/you/he/they) Only two tenses: past and non-past Regular conjugation patterns Always come at the end of sentences

sections.heading: The Three Verb Groups
sections.content: Every Japanese verb belongs to one of three groups. Knowing which group determines how to conjugate it.

children.heading: Group 1: Godan Verbs (五段動詞)
children.content:
Also called: う-verbs, consonant-stem verbs

Rule: Dictionary form ends in -u (う, つ, る, く, ぐ, す, む, ぶ, ぬ)

書く (kaku) - to write 話す (hanasu) - to speak 飲む (nomu) - to drink 読む (yomu) - to read 行く (iku) - to go

Key feature: The ending consonant changes during conjugation.

children.heading: Group 2: Ichidan Verbs (一段動詞)
children.content:
Also called: る-verbs, vowel-stem verbs

Rule: Dictionary form ends in -eru or -iru

食べる (taberu) - to eat [e-る] 見る (miru) - to see [i-る] 寝る (neru) - to sleep [e-る] 起きる (okiru) - to wake up [i-る]

Key feature: Simply drop る and add endings.

children.heading: Group 3: Irregular Verbs (不規則動詞)
children.content:
Only two verbs:

する (suru) - to do 来る (kuru) - to come

Must memorize these separately.

children.heading: Step 1: Check if it's Irregular
children.content: Is it する or 来る? → Group 3

children.heading: Step 2: Look at the Ending
children.content:
Does it end in anything other than -eru or -iru? → Group 1

書く (kaku) - ends in ku → Group 1 話す (hanasu) - ends in su → Group 1

children.heading: Step 3: -eru/-iru Ending
children.content:
Group 2 (Ichidan): The sound before る is e or i

食べる (ta-be-ru) - be is an e sound → Group 2 見る (mi-ru) - mi is an i sound → Group 2

children.heading: Tricky Cases
children.content:
Some verbs end in -eru/-iru but are actually Group 1:

帰る (kaeru) - to return → Group 1 (exception) 走る (hashiru) - to run → Group 1 (exception) 知る (shiru) - to know → Group 1 (exception) 切る (kiru) - to cut → Group 1 (exception)

When in doubt, check a dictionary.

sections.heading: Verb Forms Overview
sections.content: Japanese verbs have several forms used for different purposes:

children.heading: Dictionary Form (辞書形)
children.content:
The base form found in dictionaries:

食べる (taberu) - to eat 行く (iku) - to go

Uses:

Plain/casual present/future Before certain particles In plain speech

children.heading: Masu Form (ます形)
children.content:
Polite present/future form:

食べます (tabemasu) - eat/will eat 行きます (ikimasu) - go/will go

Uses:

Polite conversation Standard business language Safe default for learners

children.heading: Te-form (て形)
children.content:
Connective form:

食べて (tabete) - eating and... 行って (itte) - going and...

Uses:

Connecting actions Making requests (〜てください) Progressive (〜ている) Many grammar patterns

children.heading: Ta-form (た形)
children.content:
Plain past form:

食べた (tabeta) - ate 行った (itta) - went

Uses:

Plain past tense Casual conversation Many grammar patterns

children.heading: Nai-form (ない形)
children.content:
Plain negative form:

食べない (tabenai) - don't eat 行かない (ikanai) - don't go

Uses:

Plain negative Before certain grammar patterns

children.heading: Group 1 (Godan) - 書く (kaku)
children.content: Dictionary: 書く (kaku) - write Masu: 書きます (kakimasu) Te-form: 書いて (kaite) Ta-form: 書いた (kaita) Nai-form: 書かない (kakanai)

children.heading: Group 2 (Ichidan) - 食べる (taberu)
children.content: Dictionary: 食べる (taberu) - eat Masu: 食べます (tabemasu) Te-form: 食べて (tabete) Ta-form: 食べた (tabeta) Nai-form: 食べない (tabenai)

children.heading: Group 3 (Irregular) - する (suru)
children.content: Dictionary: する (suru) - do Masu: します (shimasu) Te-form: して (shite) Ta-form: した (shita) Nai-form: しない (shinai)

children.heading: Group 3 (Irregular) - 来る (kuru)
children.content: Dictionary: 来る (kuru) - come Masu: 来ます (kimasu) Te-form: 来て (kite) Ta-form: 来た (kita) Nai-form: 来ない (konai)

sections.heading: Tense System
sections.content: Japanese only has two tenses : non-past and past.

children.heading: Non-Past (Present/Future)
children.content:
私は寿司を食べる "I eat sushi" / "I will eat sushi" 明日学校に行く "I will go to school tomorrow"

Context determines present vs future.

children.heading: Past
children.content: 私は寿司を食べた "I ate sushi" 昨日学校に行った "I went to school yesterday"

children.heading: Plain (Dictionary Form)
children.content: 食べる - eat Used with: - Friends - Family - Casual settings - Before certain particles

children.heading: Polite (Masu Form)
children.content: 食べます - eat (polite) Used with: - Strangers - Formal settings - Business situations - When in doubt

children.heading: Honorific/Humble
children.content: Special forms for very polite situations (see Keigo ).

children.heading: Transitive (takes を)
children.content: 開ける (akeru) - to open (something) ドアを開ける - open the door

children.heading: Intransitive (no を)
children.content:
開く (aku) - to open (by itself) ドアが開く - the door opens

See: Transitive & Intransitive

children.heading: Action + ます
children.content: 食べます (tabemasu) - eat 飲みます (nomimasu) - drink 行きます (ikimasu) - go

children.heading: Negation
children.content: 食べません (tabemasen) - don't eat 食べませんでした (tabemasendeshita) - didn't eat

children.heading: Past
children.content: 食べました (tabemashita) - ate 行きました (ikimashita) - went

children.heading: Suru Verbs
children.content:
Many nouns + する become verbs:

勉強 (benkyou) - study → 勉強する (benkyou suru) - to study 掃除 (souji) - cleaning → 掃除する (souji suru) - to clean 電話 (denwa) - phone → 電話する (denwa suru) - to phone

Conjugate the する part:

勉強します (polite) 勉強した (past) 勉強しない (negative)

children.heading: Daily Actions
children.content: 食べる (taberu) - eat [Group 2] 飲む (nomu) - drink [Group 1] 見る (miru) - see/watch [Group 2] 聞く (kiku) - hear/listen [Group 1] 話す (hanasu) - speak [Group 1]

children.heading: Movement
children.content: 行く (iku) - go [Group 1] 来る (kuru) - come [Group 3] 帰る (kaeru) - return home [Group 1] 歩く (aruku) - walk [Group 1] 走る (hashiru) - run [Group 1]

children.heading: Basic Actions
children.content: する (suru) - do [Group 3] 読む (yomu) - read [Group 1] 書く (kaku) - write [Group 1] 買う (kau) - buy [Group 1] 売る (uru) - sell [Group 1]

children.heading: States
children.content: ある (aru) - exist (inanimate) [Group 1] いる (iru) - exist (animate) [Group 2] 寝る (neru) - sleep [Group 2] 起きる (okiru) - wake up [Group 2] 座る (suwaru) - sit [Group 1]

children.heading: Understanding
children.content: 分かる (wakaru) - understand [Group 1] 知る (shiru) - know [Group 1] 思う (omou) - think [Group 1] 考える (kangaeru) - consider [Group 2] 忘れる (wasureru) - forget [Group 2]

sections.heading: Verb Position in Sentences
sections.content:
Verbs always come at the end:

私は毎日日本語を勉強します watashi wa mainichi nihongo wo benkyou shimasu I (topic) everyday Japanese (object) study "I study Japanese every day"

Even with multiple clauses, each verb ends its clause:

朝ごはんを食べて、学校に行きました Ate breakfast and went to school

children.heading: Mistake 1: Wrong Group Classification
children.content:
Wrong: 食べます → 食ます ❌ Right: 食べます ✓

Don't drop べ - it's Group 2 (Ichidan).

children.heading: Mistake 2: Using Wrong Conjugation Pattern
children.content: Wrong: 書けます ❌ (treating as Group 2) Right: 書きます ✓ (Group 1)

children.heading: Mistake 3: Forgetting Politeness Match
children.content:
Mixed: 私は学生ですが、寿司を食べる ❌ Consistent: 私は学生ですが、寿司を食べます ✓

Match politeness throughout sentence.

children.heading: Mistake 4: Verb Not Last
children.content: Wrong: 私は食べる寿司を ❌ Right: 私は寿司を食べる ✓

sections.heading: Quick Reference Table
sections.content: | Group | Example | Masu | Te-form | Past | | ------------- | ------- | -------- | ------- | ------ | | 1 (Godan) | 書く | 書きます | 書いて | 書いた | | 2 (Ichidan) | 食べる | 食べます | 食べて | 食べた | | 3 (Irregular) | する | します | して | した | | 3 (Irregular) | 来る | 来ます | 来て | 来た |

sections.heading: Practice Method
sections.content: Learn group classification - identify verbs correctly Master masu form first - safe, polite default Practice common verbs - the 25 above cover daily needs Learn te-form - unlocks many grammar patterns Add plain forms gradually - for casual speech

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
✓ Three groups: Godan, Ichidan, Irregular ✓ Only two tenses: non-past and past ✓ Same form for all persons (I/you/he/they) ✓ Always sentence-final ✓ Conjugation is regular within each group ✓ Learn group membership first

Understanding verb basics is essential - they form the core of every sentence and unlock all advanced grammar patterns.
